page.title: 13LANDSCAPE OF CURY/GUNWALLOE
page.content: During the Mid Devonian period of rock building (350-400 million years ago) the area was submerged beneath the seas. Much sedimentation took place laying down the Gramscatho and Mylor Beds consisting mainly of slate. From such slate has the present land scape formed resulting in an expanse of quite fertile undulating grassland intersected by a relatively steep valley system with sharp breaks of slope; caused by spring fed streams and river. The valleys being more densely foliaged. At the lower reaches the river has formed a marshy flood plain and is banked by windblown sand hills. The general height of the undulating landscape ranges from 50'- 70' above sea level. The coastline comprises of cliffs (e.g. Halzephron Cliff) rocky/sandy coves and pebbly beach/bar from Gunwalloe to Loe Bar.
